IV. The Importance of Renewable Energy in Precision Farming

* Discuss the importance of renewable energy in precision farming, including the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and the potential for energy independence
* Provide examples of renewable energy sources being used in precision farming, such as solar, wind, and biogas
* Renewable energy sources can greatly reduce the environmental impact of precision farming by decreasing the use of fossil fuels. In a study by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, the use of renewable energy in precision farming can reduce greenhouse gas emissions by up to 70%. (Source: <https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy15osti/63820.pdf>)
* Chart 4: Reduction of Greenhouse Gas Emissions with Renewable Energy in Precision Farming
* One example of a precision farming operation using renewable energy is Green Energy Farms, a farm in California that uses a combination of solar and biogas to power their hydroponic greenhouse. (Source: <https://www.greenenergyfarms.net/>)

V. Building Sustainable Communities through Precision Farming

* Discuss the potential for precision farming to contribute to sustainable and resilient communities
* Describe how precision farming can contribute to circular economy by reducing waste and promoting efficient use of resources
* Provide examples of precision farming initiatives that are positively impacting local communities
* Precision farming can play a key role in building sustainable communities by providing a reliable source of fresh, locally grown produce. In a study by the World Bank, precision farming can increase food security in developing communities by up to 50%. (Source: <https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/agriculture/brief/precision-agriculture-and-sustainable-development>)
* Chart 5: Increase in Food Security with Precision Farming in Developing Communities
* One example of a precision farming initiative positively impacting a local community is the "Growing Power" program in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. This program provides training and resources for urban farmers to grow food using hydroponics and aquaponics, with the goal of increasing food access and economic opportunities for low-income residents. (Source: <https://www.growingpower.org/>)
